Culinary Profile & Uses

1. Flavour and Form ‘FoodFin’ offers a surprisingly delicate, sweet flavor with a clean, white flesh and a firm, medium-flake texture. It lacks the strong, earthy notes often associated with bottom-feeding carp species, thanks to its controlled herbivorous diet and suspended feeding habits. The fish has a deep-bodied, athletic form with brassy-gold and olive coloration, bred for muscle mass over flowing fins.

2. The Mild, Sustainable Whitefish This fish’s mildness and firm texture make it an excellent “utility” protein, adaptable to various cuisines where it readily absorbs accompanying flavors.

  • Whole Steaming or Baking: The premier method for smaller fish; steaming with ginger, scallions, and a light soy dressing highlights its natural sweetness and tender flesh.
  • Fish Balls and Cakes: Its firm, low-fat flesh binds well, making it ideal for creating light, springy fish balls for soups or pan-fried fish cakes.
  • Crispy Fried Whole: Small fish can be fried whole until the bones are edible and crisp, a popular preparation in many Asian cuisines that minimizes waste.
  • Poached and Flaked: Gently poached and flaked, it can be used in salads, stuffings, or as a protein topping for grain bowls.

3. The Growth & Harvest Cycle ‘FoodFin’ is a highly efficient grazer, thriving on a diet of duckweed, softened vegetables, and high-quality plant-based pellets. Its sterility (triploidy) means all metabolic energy is directed toward growth rather than reproduction. In an integrated aquaponics system, a cohort provides a steady, sustainable yield of 15-25 fish per 100-liter barrel, reaching optimal harvest size of 250g in 6-8 months, while providing excellent nutrient conversion for plant growth.
